qas.question: Where does cancellation of any reactance seen?
What is left after antenna tuning?
What can be used to cancel a inductibe reactance or residual capacitative?
What is an antenna designed to have?

context: Antenna tuning generally refers to cancellation of any reactance seen at the <a0_0>antenna terminals<a0_0/>, leaving only a <a1_0>resistive impedance<a1_0/> which might or might not be exactly the desired impedance (that of the transmission line). Although an antenna may be designed to have a <a3_0>purely resistive feedpoint<a3_0/> impedance (such as a dipole 97% of a half wavelength long) this might not be exactly true at the frequency that it is eventually used at. In some cases the physical length of the antenna can be "trimmed" to obtain a pure resistance. On the other hand, the addition of a series inductance or <a2_0>parallel capacitance<a2_0/> can be used to cancel a residual capacitative or inductive reactance, respectively.
